Я утверждаю,что пространство это время.А время это пространство.Пространство и время тождественны.Это одно и то же.Нет времени без пространства,и нет пространства без времени.Для преодоления пространства требуется время/затрачивается время.Для осознания времени требуется пространство/преодоление пространства.Когда вы смотрите вдаль/на что-то вдали,вы видите время,требуемое для его преодоления до объекта на котором ваш взор.При этом кто-то скажет что в этот момент я его не преодолеваю.Это так.В этот момент его преодолевает электромагнитная волна - свет,которая "доносит" до вас не только свет,но и "осознание" пространства-времени.Кто-то скажет,я закрою глаза,и отключив визуализацию пространства,которое "несёт" мне свет,я по идее должен остановить и время.По идее да,но в этот момент ваше сердце гонит кровь,по венам,которая преодолевает пространство,ограниченное кровеносными сосудами,затрачивая на это время.Пространство-время прямопропорционально зависит от приложеной энергии для его преодоления.Когда вы идёте пешком оно имеет одну величину.Когда вы увеличиваете энергию преодоления,например едете на автомобиле,время-пространство сокращаются,и так далее.Для каждого,начальная константа личного пространства-времени,определяется личными биологическими процессами.Но они не сильно различаются,так как природа индивидуумов одна и та же,при этом усредняется придумаными механизмами.Например часами.Я утверждаю,что этот прибор,измеряет приложеную энергию на преодоление пространства-времени.

More recently (1990s), atoms adsorbed on crystal surfaces have been imaged with atomic force micropes and/or scanning tunneling microscopes (and the results published in peer-reviewed journals).  So imaging individual atoms is not so new.

I think "Physics Girl" made a mistake in this video. She said that an electron is not made of any smaller particles, but I recall reading somewhere that each electron, like a proton, is composed of three tightly bound together quarks.

Apparently, there is a limit to how small a piece of matter can get and that limit exists at the level of a quark. Below that there is no "finer" substructure which suggests that each quark is somehow made up of pure energy that "condenses" to form the quark. When you break up a quark, it's mass is just released as pure electromagnetic energy. I sometimes wonder, however, if most of the zoo-like collection of subatomic particles contained in the "standard model" actually exists in the real universe. Maybe those particle physicists are slamming protons together with energies that are actually exceeding anything that naturally occurs in the cosmos or even existed during the Big Bang. If that's the case, then basing theories upon these particles and saying they apply to the real cosmos might be a HUGE error. Well, time will tell. Meanwhile, it's interesting to see what will come of all of these accelerator experiments and ad hoc theories. So far, I've seen nothing practical emerge from any of it despite the billions invested.

Something I've never got about string theory is if strings are one dimensional, then in a three dimensional space you still have a problem with infinities. Sure the characteristics are distributed over the string, but if you're just considering a cross-section of the string you still gets points which must have characteristics, so you still get locations with infinite forces, and in fact you get infinitely many of them. Yet paradoxically the string has finite values for its characteristics... exactly as with point particles. So, how is this any sort of actual resolution to the problem we have with calculating the properties of point particles?

Do you think it is likely that the truly smallest "thing" in the universe is a Planck length? If so, I don't think we're anywhere close to sufficient energies to "see" it, that is, to detect its existence and measure its physical size. Perhaps though, the Planck Length only defines the smallest length (or area, or volume) that could exist in our universe, but not necessarily that actually does exist. Maybe nothing is actually that small, not even in the structure of space? But then, there are lots of masses much smaller than the Planck Mass, so could there be lengths < the PL?

All this speculation aside, this is a nice video on "seeing" at really minute scales, ones way smaller than the light that eyes actually see by.

I appreciate the author's good work---public education is a scientist's highest calling, and it's people like her who are pulling up the slack from people like me.

That said, I think this video is misleading at times. And do please forgive the criticism. It is truly meant to be constructive.

My biggest gripe is that you implied that we need string theory to model fundamental particles, and ignored that fact that we actually don't use string-theory in mainstream science. String theory is a very interesting and promising and may one day be our most fundamental description of the universe. But right now, it isn't exactly science yet. There is no experimental data which supports it. 

The generally accepted model of fundamental particles is based in quantum field theory and is called the standard model. The reason fundamental particles 'have no size' (as you put it) is because particles are manifestations of vibrations in fields, and vibrations (waves) don't exist with a well defined edge. There is an electron field, and quark field, etc, and particles are quantized excitations in those fields, and because those vibrations are quantized (that is, have characterizing quantities which are tied to integer numbers), we call them quantum fields. Those integer numbers are the 'particles'.

In fact, you hailed the discovery of the Higgs, which was introduced as a theoretical quantity---a mathematical workaround---in order to allow the standard model to work. This is why many people were so surprised to find it! The predictive power of the standard model is incredible, and is the standard basis on which we model the fundamental constituents of our world. I know string theory is the bigger buzz-word, but in the interest of an accurate portrayal of the state of scientific thinking, I think you should have at least mentioned the standard model.

I have two big problems with this video. 

1. Giving string theory (p'too) a mention, despite its long history of being unfalsifiable, making zero predictions, and relying on the ever-more-implausible idea of supersymmetry that the LHC failed to find.

2. Calling the Planck length "the smallest length possible" as if that was something that was true, rather than something that is theorized only in theories of quantum gravity, which, as a field, is so wildly unsuccessful that something as pitiful as string theory has managed to fart around taking up grant money for thirty years.  I'd be okay with mentioning it if you clarified that this idea is merely the domain of non-rigorous conjecture (well-motivated, sure, but not a rigorous theory).

Also, this is more of a minor issue, but you talked about three different ideas of size (de Broglie wavelength (the photons and electrons for the purposes of microscopy), wave function spread (imaging the molecule and hydrogen atom), and internal structure (talking of fundamental particles as points)) without fully clarifying the differences between them.  Honestly, in the world of quantum, the idea of "size" isn't particularly well-defined or useful, which kind of makes a mockery of the idea of "the smallest thing in the universe."
